title: Sebastien Vahaamahina red card gives Wales dramatic win over France
text:
Vahaamahina’s red card was a key turning point in Wales’ clash with France (Picture: Getty)

Wales recovered from three first-half French tries to win 20-19 and edge into the Rugby World Cup semi-finals thanks to a moment of madness from Sebastien Vahaamahina.

Warren Gatland’s side were outplayed in the first half and even after Vahaamahina’s dismissal for a deliberate elbow to the face of Aaron Wainwright, it looked as though Welsh hearts might be broken.

But replacement No 8 Ross Moriarty scored with five minutes to go to give Wales a one-point lead and a place in the last four of the World Cup.

Wales were forced into a last-minute change by Jonathan Davies, who did not make it through Saturday’s captain’s run and was replaced by Owen Watkin.

Moriarty scored the crucial try (Picture: Getty)

But it is difficult to imagine any version of the Wales team being able to resist the start that France produced, with Vaahamina and then Ollivon the main beneficiaries of a breath-taking pace.

The Welsh did hit back quickly, Wainwright scoring his first international try after a thumping hit from Hadleigh Parkes on Guilhem Guirado knocked the ball free on the French 22.

But an injury to Josh Navidi and a yellow card for his replacement Ross Moriarty a minute later left Wales vulnerable and Vakatawa, whose chin had felt the full force of the substitute’s illegal tackle.

However, Moriarty’s indiscretion was long forgotten just nine minutes after half-time when Vahaamina’s had a rush of blood the head, throwing a forceful elbow into the face of Wainwright and once referee Jaco Peyper had seen it on the big screen, there was little doubt as to what would follow.

As is often the case, the red card seem to galvanise the 14 men of France but Wales resisted the urge to panic, first converting a penalty to reduce the deficit to just six points and then kicking their way back into French territory.

Wales edged the game by a point (Picture: Getty)

And if Moriarty needed any further redemption, it came in the 74th minute when Tomos Williams, stripped the ball at the back of a French five-metre scrum, Justin Tipuric seized on the loose ball and the No 8 scored from the very next phase.

The kick from Dan Biggar edged Wales into the lead and they were able to eek out the last five minutes to reach the semi-finals.
